awd_abstract_narration: Hopa Mountain, a Bozeman, MT based nonprofit organization, in collaboration with the Blackfeet Native Science Field Center at Blackfeet Community College, is scaling up their Track 2 Native Science Fellows program to engage up to 20 Native American college students annually in community-based geosciences field experiences and careers.  Working together, these organizations provide role models and work experience for Native American tribal college and university students interested in the geosciences; develop an annual Fellows gathering with peer networks of Native college students that are interested in pursuing geosciences careers; and strengthen the network of colleges, organizations and science professionals who are committed to the success of Native students, providing students with on-going support for personal, academic and professional success.  Additionally, the Blackfeet Native Science Field Center is organizing a week-long Native Science Summer Institute for 25 secondary students.  These career-ladder fellowship programs are designed to expand the number of Native American students in the Northern Rockies that are pursuing geosciences degrees and careers.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: GLOB LEARN & OBSER TO BEN ENVI

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Native Science Fellows program organized by Hopa Mountain and Blackfeet Community College's Native Science Field Center engaged Native American high school, college, and graduate students in community-based geosciences field programs and research projects to prepare them to succeed academically and professionally in geosciences careers. There were four primary program goals: (1) To increase the number of Native American geosciences students who were engaged in community-based geosciences education and careers; (2) To provide role models and geosciences work experiences for Native American students; (3) To develop a career ladder network of students interested in geosciences careers; and (4) To build a network of geosciences professionals who are committed to the success of these students. Over a five year period, more than 107 students participated in the Native Science Fellows program initiatives. Fourty-seven students were in high school and completed summer geosciences field programs. Sixty of these students were college Fellows. Of these students, 5 completed an Associates degree, 15 completed a Bachelors degree, 4 completed Masters degrees, and 1 completed a Ph.D. in the geosciences. The program provided support for all of these students to work with community-based science organizations and professional mentors that continue to invest in their success.


Last Modified: 10/12/2016
Modified by: Bonnie L Sachatello-Sawyer
